headline: 'The Five' on Harris' trip to border, Biden's 'bizarre' news conference

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters, Katie Pavlich, Jessica Tarlov, Martha MacCallum, and Greg Gutfeld. It's five o'clock in New York City and this is The Five.

utterances.speaker: PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: How did you decide that right now was the right time to make your first trip to the border?

utterances.speaker: KAMALA HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Well, it's not my first trip. I visit the border many times.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.sentences: As vice president --

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Back in March that I was going to come to the border, so this is not a new plan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It only took 93 days, but Kamala Harris finally visited the border. Kind of. The V.P. snapping at our own Peter Doocy there and claims that seeing the situation firsthand was always the plan even though she repeatedly left off questions about going and Republicans have been pressuring Harris to visit for months. Now instead of touring the epicenter of this crisis she was hundreds of miles away from the where the most serious problems are. And Harris didn't to offer up solutions to stop the surge of migrants coming across. Instead, she pointed the finger at the last administration and focused on her favorite phrase root causes. While insisting everything is totally under control.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: As you know, we inherited a tough situation. We have seen streak progress over the last few months. This issue cannot be reduced to a political issue. We're talking about children. We are talking about families. We're talking about suffering, and our approach has to be thoughtful and effective. I'm committed to ensuring that we engage in an active way on the root causes. The focus that we have place on the root causes. Invest in the root causes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Democratic Congressman Veronica Escobar who is traveling with the V.P. today getting a lot of attention for saying this.

utterances.speaker: REP. VERONICA ESCOBAR (D-TX)
utterances.sentences: Welcome to El Paso. Welcome to my community. To the new Ellis Island, to the capital of the border. I am standing before you with a heartful of gratitude. Madame Vice President, thank you for being here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, Martha, you covered a lot of this this afternoon. What jumped out at you today?

utterances.speaker: MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Well, that comment jumps out of me. I mean, that is not Ellis Island. Ellis Island doesn't work where you've got a big hole in the fence and people like, you know, just make their way through. Ellis Island is a process. You have, you know, back then you had to go through it. There is still a process now to become an American citizen. And a lot of people go through it and do it the right way. I also thought it was strange that Congresswoman Escobar said, you know, this is where we greet Americans as they come across the border. This is a dangerous journey, when I listen to the vice president talk about how we have to be so concerned about these children and we have to care about them, and you know, that they were -- that they inherited this disaster, I just can't help but think about these children that get dropped over the fence by themselves after being left by coyotes and they're screaming in the night holding their teddy bear asking someone to help them. I'm not sure how this is a more humane system than what we had before. Granted there were, you know, legitimate questions about what was done before, but I'm not sure how this has become, you know, where all the progress is and how this is going so much better at this point remains to be seen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Katie, she didn't actually went to the border. She went to the airport and then she went to a border patrol station that wasn't actually on the border and then a processing facility. It's almost like she's insulting our intelligence.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Isn't the rule that if a place doesn't count that you've been to unless you actually leave the airport?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right. So, she went to the border patrol facility, didn't go to the actual border. Well, there is a wall there so maybe they didn't want the optics of the vice president standing in front of the border well that was replaced by the Trump administration. I'm calling this the nothing to see here tour, because they don't want to go to McAllen because then they would see all of what's actually happening. She claims that this about children and people and humanity. Well, it would be nice if you want to visit them and talk with them and maybe listen to some of the stories about their journey and how they got here and what the root causes are and why they decided to make that journey and talk to those people firsthand. And the other thing that was so interesting about the comment made by the congresswoman and she says it's the new Ellis Island. Ellis Island was a welcoming place for people who wanted to become American citizens. Well, it didn't -- the vice president just go to Guatemala and say don't come?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, she is undermining the administration's whole point of don't come. So, when they say that there's been progress, they're talking about if their goal is allowing as many people as possible into the country without any kind of system, well, that goal is being reached every single month in record numbers. But if the goal is to somehow stop the flow or actually find out what's going on, she's not meeting with the people who are making the journey to find out why they left in the first place.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, she says that there's been progress, Jessica. There has not been progress, don't disagree, I don't have the effort today. There is just no progress. Why would she lie like that?

utterances.speaker: JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: I wouldn't call it lying, I understand it's Friday, though. So, in that spirit I think we can just have an adult conversation about what goes on at the border under every administration. Everyone has this problem. Right? Decades' old problem. I'm not saying the numbers aren't spiking right now, Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I heard the little gesture. I'm taking account of it. I did think that it was a missed opportunity to not have one someone like Congressman Cuellar who is actually a border -- who is also a representative of a border state but in a higher influx migrant area let's say with her who has called it out and said, I don't need a photo up, we need actual help here. And AOC and a number of the other representatives have visited the facilities, said these facilities for kids are unacceptable. I don't think that those kinds of things and showing compassion and talking to kids talking to parents who have made this journey makes you look worse or makes your policies look worse because every administration struggle with this. And unless you're super polarized like the people on really the far left or the far right about it, I think people understand how complicated this issue his and would be amenable to listening about what the solutions are and just what you heard from people, what their journey was like, the humanity side of that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I feel like she doesn't want to go to that facility in McAllen or the Rio Grande Valley because she doesn't want images of her --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes, of course.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- in that situation that can be use against her in the Democrat primary. The squad will kill her with those pictures. She owns that. She's a part of this administration, she doesn't want to be associated with it so she dodged it and went to El Paso, West Texas, 800 miles away. Greg, you've been wanting to talk about this all afternoon. I will give you the last word.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was up all-night thinking about this stuff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You were.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But you know what, Ellis Island is what they really believe. That's what you just saw the slip showing. It shows the gulf between what they want America to believe and what they really believe. Which is why. When people say both parties are struggling with this. The reason why both parties are struggling is because one party really doesn't believe that the border needs to be that strong. Right? They don't believe it. If they did, they would have at least told people not to come and would have kept the wall there which was the only variable -- new variable that we had in this debate since I've been on this planet, that was the -- that's the first time I've never ever seen an actual change in the debate which caused everybody to hate it. She seems very defensive, doesn't she?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She reminds me of me when my wife goes with the MX bill, you know? And she keeps citing -- she cites root causes more than a tree surgeon which she should be really citing root solutions. And there are solutions. I just mentioned one. But they can't -- they can't seek practical solutions if they were somehow linked to either Trump or the Republican Party, so instead she treats it like a chore. She's like, she's like when your parents make you take a young sibling to the movies, that's what she acts like when she went to the border. She really didn't want to be there.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She didn't want to be there. And she feels like she has to be there because she's being made to go there and she's so defensive about it. It really is interesting that she's supposed to be the successor for 2024, right now there has to be some buyer's remorse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. She seems uncomfortable with the mantle of the vice president spirit.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: She didn't want to go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She didn't want to go.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, she didn't really want to go.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: It's a thankless job. It was for Joe Biden as well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She didn't think she has to do something like this. Well, thankless?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it's just very obvious that she has no interest --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Yes, thankless.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- in solving the problem.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Listen to how she's being talked about constantly.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: She is doing nothing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wasn't thankless for George Bush 41.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It's her job. But what has she done that says (Inaudible) she deserves praise for?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He got the White House after eight years.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Name one thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You can't.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You can't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You can't do it. You can't do it. You can't do it, Jessica. And it's Friday.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Give me more time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm just glad we had an adult conversation, Jessica.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Unlike those other days.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Thank you for bringing so much maturity to the table.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm here for.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Ahead. Derek Chauvin speaking for the first time before being sentenced in the murder of George Floyd. How long he'll spend behind bars is next.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Breaking news in Minneapolis this afternoon. Derek Chauvin speaking out for the first since his trial began right before a judge sentenced the former police officer to 22 and a half years in prison for the murder of George Floyd. Chauvin giving this very cryptic statement first time he has spoken out. Watch what said.

utterances.speaker: DEREK CHAUVIN, FORMER POLICE OFFICER
utterances.sentences: There are some additional legal matters at hand. I'm not able to give the full formal statement at this time. But for briefly though, I do want to give my condolences to the Floyd family. There is going to be some other information in the future that would be of interest. I hope things will give you some peace of mind.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Jesse, what do you think that means?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think he is a sick puppy. I think he's got maniacal look in his eyes. I would not leave the family hanging like a cliffhanger during that situation. He is a really disturbed individual. Perhaps he is looking at life if you tap on the federal indictments to federal indictments on top of the 22 years. He's never going to see the light of day. And he knows as a cop, someone like that goes into prison, you have to be solitary confinement the whole time. If they go to the general, they're going to eat him alive. So, he's a dead man if he steps outside into general pop. So, he might have to off himself, maybe he was saying that, I don't know, I'm not inside his sick head. It's just a theory. Or there is some legal mumbo-jumbo he is going to unveil later with his team. I have no idea, but that was a very weird thing to do to the family at that time who are grieving. I just look back at the situation, this George Floyd death. I am so glad we are turning the page on this chapter in American history. I can't think of any positive thing that came out of this and I'm a silver lining kind of guy. The death, the destruction, the police retirements, the crime wave, the racial resentment, what good has come out of this? What concrete results have come out of this death and the aftermath? I can't think of it. Someone help me, but it's been all bad.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: I'm right here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Tell me.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Go ahead, Jess.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: So, the one thing or one -- I haven't thought this broadly. But one thing that is a good result is this extreme sentencing of Derek Chauvin. That there is accountability and I understand there are many people --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: -- probably including -

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We expected that. We expected that.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Jesse, that's completely unfair. I can't think of one thing that I said one thing --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, of course I'm glad he got locked up and that's fine. I'm talking about society.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: But that does matter for a society because now there is an example of a white police officer who took the life of a black man on camera in front of everyone and he went away for a really long time. Now it's not as long as some people would have wanted some social justice advocates. I don't know what the Floyd family was hoping for 30 years. But nobody can dispute the fact that this was a substantive sentence for a killer. And we sought other members of the police force get up there and say we don't teach people to do that. He is not one of us. This is not how we do things. And I think that all of that is incredibly important. Those are two good things.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That I agree with you but that's what so tragic about the extrapolation of his act that has reflected on police officers all across the country. I mean, that's what so devastating about it. And I think back to that night in Minneapolis when Mayor Jacob Frey told those police officers in the third precinct get out of there. That to me, that was one of the most crucial turning point of the entire summer that followed. Because he didn't say we've got your back, hold the fort, we are going to make sure that we, you know, we quell what's going on outside this precinct. They got in their cars and they rode away. They never got over that, those police officers. They never got over it. They abandoned their post. People ran in there. They flooded the entire place, they emptied the filing cabinets. It was so repulsive I think in such a deep way. And Jacob Frey, so now they're having elections to the city council where they all said they were going to reimagine the police force after that, right? And now, what's happened is that everyone on that city council, they didn't meet the margin of 60 percent so they now have to basically go to a runoff.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So now Jacob Frey also is expected he is the refund the police man now, Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right. Right.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, he's expected to win in that election.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, that's the biggest problem with the consequences of the aftermath of the situation because the left took this case and apply it to every single police department across the country no matter if it's in a big city, in small town, all cops are racist, they had to be defunded. You had a number of Democratic city councils and mayors all over the place, Portland, Minneapolis, Baltimore, defunding the police and then all of a sudden crime goes up by. you know, murders are up 50 percent in some places. In Portland homicide is up by 500 plus percent in that city. And now all of a sudden you have the president this week coming in with essentially a crime bail out for these blue cities by saying you can take money from the American Rescue Act to refund your police forces that you took millions of dollars away from because you were buying into this narrative. That by the way, the prosecution didn't use it in court. The prosecution said Derek Chauvin is one officer in a force. He murdered George Floyd. That was the argument they made. The jury agreed with them. But the left took it and applied it to everybody else and we had a year of rage and summers of burning. And you have the White House now trying to get out in front of another summer like that because police are leaving in droves, people are not signing up to replace the people who are retiring. And people want more police in their communities. And so, there are consequences to applying the situation to everyone rather than just taking the fact as they were for this one case.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: We go back to the summer, Greg, and you know, you remember during the election, how much the need to reform police was such a big topic and now, you know, this is like front and center on the place of President Biden and Kamala Harris and you know, now we're at a whole different stage of this. But they are still, you know, dealing with an issue that became difficult for them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, what do we do now? Our politicians and our media decided to use this case to indict the entire -- our entire national police force, which led to the defunding, led to the Ferguson effect, dramatic shocking rise in crime in which most of the victims were black and brown. Right? I mean, they're all in cities that really needed law enforcement. And the law enforcement was no longer there. That created a mountain of dead. And that was driven by, in my view, like - - just taking a -- they are something like 25 to 30 cases like this every year out of millions and millions of stops and they're horrible and they're tragic, and that was -- the guy is going away for a long time. But we didn't spend any time really on that Puerto Rican couple.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know? From the parade who were pulled out of their car and murdered.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And I keep thinking about that one because there are so many horrible criminal acts that have been going on that the media decides is not important. It's not important. It is important when the police officer does something because of the job that they hold, they're in authority figure and it places until the racial elements. But when you think about OK, if you play through your mind and you find the very worst things, that crime turn my stomach because you saw it. It's as bad as what we saw with the police.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It's horrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's horrible. And I wonder what would have happened if the cops were there. They weren't there, and they had stopped that crime and they had shot one of the suspects? How would the media portrayed that when that husband and wife are alive and the kids now still have their parents, but there is a dead suspect or an injured suspect. How would that have been portrayed if the cop --it would be in entirely different story and there be -- I have no idea what it would be like. I could predict that the police would be portrayed in a favorable way.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well we know, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: LeBron James when you had that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- that police officer in Ohio who shot that girl who was stabbing the other girl.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Immediately blew up as a racial incident of police violence when he saved the life of a young black girl.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: And so, you know, they've racialized all of these situations immediately when they come out, rather than waiting for the facts and treating each case as an individual situation rather than smearing all police officers as being like Derek Chauvin.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. And each case is different.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There aren't a lot of them. So, you could act, if you were a journalist you could sit down and actually read about every single case like this --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- it'd be done in three weeks and come to the conclusion that there are all sorts of variables involved from police incompetence, right? Police brutality, substances, crowd control, all of these things play a role differently, each one of them. But the media cannot abide by that. They cannot look at the nuances, it all has to be black and white and black versus white.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Well, there is some nuance which I think is really interesting between media coverage and actually public approval of law enforcement and what people want. And Eric Adams, who looks to becoming the new mayor of New York has already started talking about that. Of New York City.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: You know, and he is a police officer and there is high approval for law enforcement. People want more cops in their areas especially blacks --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. Because they have seen the reality of what happens when they're gone.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, this is what happened. Right? There were major consequences to this narrative that, you know, basically discouraged police from doing their job all across the country. Somebody has to -- somebody has to pay the piper for that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's the white liberal -- it's the white liberal mayor.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, it is unreal what happened. No. Yes, it is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I mean, think about -- think about Portland.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And think about Minneapolis.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And thankfully the jury in this case and the way it was prosecuted for Derek Chauvin, they did isolate it. And that's what America should have done.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Said, this is what happened. This is wrong and we need to fix it. And you know, today we have a sentence for him. So. All right. So, here's what's coming up. A totally different topic. Actually, whisper this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: President Biden whispered at a press conference and it caused quite a story. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, the hash tag creepy Joe trending on Twitter after a truly bizarre moment when President Biden aggressively whispered into a microphone. Viewer warning, it's pretty weird.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: They said that people are waiting for relief.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I got them $1.9 trillion release so far. They are going to getting checks in the mail that are consequential this week for child care. Just remind them, I wrote the bill on the environment. Why would I not before it? Pay them more. This is an employee's -- employee's bargaining chip now what's happening?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, Greg, I just imagine Joe Biden doing the whisper thing while he is touching or sniffing someone's hair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't know. Does he know that everyone can hear him? Like generally when you whisper --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I couldn't hear him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- when you whisper, it so people can't hear you, but he is whispering and everybody can hear him because he's got a microphone. Look, it's one to -- like why is he doing this? Because he's pretending that he's stating something that is obvious. Right. Pay them more. Except that's a really stupid comment. It's kind of stupid.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It's really dumb.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's like that's not the beginning and the end of an opinion although he would be really great as a character in a horror movie. I was discussing this earlier that if they ever do a horror film that takes place in an abandoned library and there's this bat story where there was a male librarian who had been like, attacked by crazed kids, and he was left to die, and then he -- but he's still there. And then like years later, these other kids show up at the library, and it's whisper. They call him Whispering Joe. It sounds like a great (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It sounds like something out of a hot -- like Hogwarts. He could be like -- right? He'd come right in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Whispering at you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But, Jessica, they could also call the movie Good Old Joe, right? Because this is a habit that he has apparently. You've done your research.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Well, I like to come prepared.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, you're saying we're not prepared?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I like how Katie just insulted you with research.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Well, not the girls, babies. So, I did my research on it. It's something that he does, but I think that we can all agree as adults and have children, that there is a large contingency of Americans, mostly Democrats, some moderate Republicans, independents, who find Joe Biden charming. And this is part of his charm. It's part of his thing. I mean, I watched Donald Trump do that weird dance like on the stage at rally.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's the YMCA, Jessica.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: This is not the YMCA.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's not a weird dance. It's YMCA.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV

utterances.sentences: Katie, that was a cheap shot, but I thought it was funny. That's it for us. Have a great weekend, everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Where's Geraldo? Content and Programming Copyright 2021 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2021 VIQ Media Transcription, Inc. utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters, Katie Pavlich, Jessica Tarlov, Martha MacCallum, and Greg Gutfeld. It's five o'clock in New York City and this is The Five.

utterances.speaker: PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: How did you decide that right now was the right time to make your first trip to the border?

utterances.speaker: KAMALA HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: Well, it's not my first trip. I visit the border many times.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.utterance: As vice president --

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: Back in March that I was going to come to the border, so this is not a new plan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It only took 93 days, but Kamala Harris finally visited the border. Kind of. The V.P. snapping at our own Peter Doocy there and claims that seeing the situation firsthand was always the plan even though she repeatedly left off questions about going and Republicans have been pressuring Harris to visit for months. Now instead of touring the epicenter of this crisis she was hundreds of miles away from the where the most serious problems are. And Harris didn't to offer up solutions to stop the surge of migrants coming across. Instead, she pointed the finger at the last administration and focused on her favorite phrase root causes. While insisting everything is totally under control.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: As you know, we inherited a tough situation. We have seen streak progress over the last few months. This issue cannot be reduced to a political issue. We're talking about children. We are talking about families. We're talking about suffering, and our approach has to be thoughtful and effective. I'm committed to ensuring that we engage in an active way on the root causes. The focus that we have place on the root causes. Invest in the root causes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Democratic Congressman Veronica Escobar who is traveling with the V.P. today getting a lot of attention for saying this.

utterances.speaker: REP. VERONICA ESCOBAR (D-TX)
utterances.utterance: Welcome to El Paso. Welcome to my community. To the new Ellis Island, to the capital of the border. I am standing before you with a heartful of gratitude. Madame Vice President, thank you for being here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, Martha, you covered a lot of this this afternoon. What jumped out at you today?

utterances.speaker: MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: Well, that comment jumps out of me. I mean, that is not Ellis Island. Ellis Island doesn't work where you've got a big hole in the fence and people like, you know, just make their way through. Ellis Island is a process. You have, you know, back then you had to go through it. There is still a process now to become an American citizen. And a lot of people go through it and do it the right way. I also thought it was strange that Congresswoman Escobar said, you know, this is where we greet Americans as they come across the border. This is a dangerous journey, when I listen to the vice president talk about how we have to be so concerned about these children and we have to care about them, and you know, that they were -- that they inherited this disaster, I just can't help but think about these children that get dropped over the fence by themselves after being left by coyotes and they're screaming in the night holding their teddy bear asking someone to help them. I'm not sure how this is a more humane system than what we had before. Granted there were, you know, legitimate questions about what was done before, but I'm not sure how this has become, you know, where all the progress is and how this is going so much better at this point remains to be seen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Katie, she didn't actually went to the border. She went to the airport and then she went to a border patrol station that wasn't actually on the border and then a processing facility. It's almost like she's insulting our intelligence.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Isn't the rule that if a place doesn't count that you've been to unless you actually leave the airport?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right. So, she went to the border patrol facility, didn't go to the actual border. Well, there is a wall there so maybe they didn't want the optics of the vice president standing in front of the border well that was replaced by the Trump administration. I'm calling this the nothing to see here tour, because they don't want to go to McAllen because then they would see all of what's actually happening. She claims that this about children and people and humanity. Well, it would be nice if you want to visit them and talk with them and maybe listen to some of the stories about their journey and how they got here and what the root causes are and why they decided to make that journey and talk to those people firsthand. And the other thing that was so interesting about the comment made by the congresswoman and she says it's the new Ellis Island. Ellis Island was a welcoming place for people who wanted to become American citizens. Well, it didn't -- the vice president just go to Guatemala and say don't come?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, she is undermining the administration's whole point of don't come. So, when they say that there's been progress, they're talking about if their goal is allowing as many people as possible into the country without any kind of system, well, that goal is being reached every single month in record numbers. But if the goal is to somehow stop the flow or actually find out what's going on, she's not meeting with the people who are making the journey to find out why they left in the first place.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, she says that there's been progress, Jessica. There has not been progress, don't disagree, I don't have the effort today. There is just no progress. Why would she lie like that?

utterances.speaker: JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: I wouldn't call it lying, I understand it's Friday, though. So, in that spirit I think we can just have an adult conversation about what goes on at the border under every administration. Everyone has this problem. Right? Decades' old problem. I'm not saying the numbers aren't spiking right now, Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I heard the little gesture. I'm taking account of it. I did think that it was a missed opportunity to not have one someone like Congressman Cuellar who is actually a border -- who is also a representative of a border state but in a higher influx migrant area let's say with her who has called it out and said, I don't need a photo up, we need actual help here. And AOC and a number of the other representatives have visited the facilities, said these facilities for kids are unacceptable. I don't think that those kinds of things and showing compassion and talking to kids talking to parents who have made this journey makes you look worse or makes your policies look worse because every administration struggle with this. And unless you're super polarized like the people on really the far left or the far right about it, I think people understand how complicated this issue his and would be amenable to listening about what the solutions are and just what you heard from people, what their journey was like, the humanity side of that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I feel like she doesn't want to go to that facility in McAllen or the Rio Grande Valley because she doesn't want images of her --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, of course.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- in that situation that can be use against her in the Democrat primary. The squad will kill her with those pictures. She owns that. She's a part of this administration, she doesn't want to be associated with it so she dodged it and went to El Paso, West Texas, 800 miles away. Greg, you've been wanting to talk about this all afternoon. I will give you the last word.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was up all-night thinking about this stuff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You were.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But you know what, Ellis Island is what they really believe. That's what you just saw the slip showing. It shows the gulf between what they want America to believe and what they really believe. Which is why. When people say both parties are struggling with this. The reason why both parties are struggling is because one party really doesn't believe that the border needs to be that strong. Right? They don't believe it. If they did, they would have at least told people not to come and would have kept the wall there which was the only variable -- new variable that we had in this debate since I've been on this planet, that was the -- that's the first time I've never ever seen an actual change in the debate which caused everybody to hate it. She seems very defensive, doesn't she?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She reminds me of me when my wife goes with the MX bill, you know? And she keeps citing -- she cites root causes more than a tree surgeon which she should be really citing root solutions. And there are solutions. I just mentioned one. But they can't -- they can't seek practical solutions if they were somehow linked to either Trump or the Republican Party, so instead she treats it like a chore. She's like, she's like when your parents make you take a young sibling to the movies, that's what she acts like when she went to the border. She really didn't want to be there.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She didn't want to be there. And she feels like she has to be there because she's being made to go there and she's so defensive about it. It really is interesting that she's supposed to be the successor for 2024, right now there has to be some buyer's remorse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. She seems uncomfortable with the mantle of the vice president spirit.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: She didn't want to go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She didn't want to go.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I mean, she didn't really want to go.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: It's a thankless job. It was for Joe Biden as well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She didn't think she has to do something like this. Well, thankless?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, I think it's just very obvious that she has no interest --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Yes, thankless.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- in solving the problem.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Listen to how she's being talked about constantly.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: She is doing nothing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wasn't thankless for George Bush 41.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's her job. But what has she done that says (Inaudible) she deserves praise for?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He got the White House after eight years.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Name one thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can't.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You can't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can't do it. You can't do it. You can't do it, Jessica. And it's Friday.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Give me more time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm just glad we had an adult conversation, Jessica.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Unlike those other days.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Thank you for bringing so much maturity to the table.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: That's what I'm here for.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ahead. Derek Chauvin speaking for the first time before being sentenced in the murder of George Floyd. How long he'll spend behind bars is next.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Breaking news in Minneapolis this afternoon. Derek Chauvin speaking out for the first since his trial began right before a judge sentenced the former police officer to 22 and a half years in prison for the murder of George Floyd. Chauvin giving this very cryptic statement first time he has spoken out. Watch what said.

utterances.speaker: DEREK CHAUVIN, FORMER POLICE OFFICER
utterances.utterance: There are some additional legal matters at hand. I'm not able to give the full formal statement at this time. But for briefly though, I do want to give my condolences to the Floyd family. There is going to be some other information in the future that would be of interest. I hope things will give you some peace of mind.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Jesse, what do you think that means?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think he is a sick puppy. I think he's got maniacal look in his eyes. I would not leave the family hanging like a cliffhanger during that situation. He is a really disturbed individual. Perhaps he is looking at life if you tap on the federal indictments to federal indictments on top of the 22 years. He's never going to see the light of day. And he knows as a cop, someone like that goes into prison, you have to be solitary confinement the whole time. If they go to the general, they're going to eat him alive. So, he's a dead man if he steps outside into general pop. So, he might have to off himself, maybe he was saying that, I don't know, I'm not inside his sick head. It's just a theory. Or there is some legal mumbo-jumbo he is going to unveil later with his team. I have no idea, but that was a very weird thing to do to the family at that time who are grieving. I just look back at the situation, this George Floyd death. I am so glad we are turning the page on this chapter in American history. I can't think of any positive thing that came out of this and I'm a silver lining kind of guy. The death, the destruction, the police retirements, the crime wave, the racial resentment, what good has come out of this? What concrete results have come out of this death and the aftermath? I can't think of it. Someone help me, but it's been all bad.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I'm right here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Tell me.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Go ahead, Jess.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: So, the one thing or one -- I haven't thought this broadly. But one thing that is a good result is this extreme sentencing of Derek Chauvin. That there is accountability and I understand there are many people --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: -- probably including -

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We expected that. We expected that.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Jesse, that's completely unfair. I can't think of one thing that I said one thing --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, of course I'm glad he got locked up and that's fine. I'm talking about society.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: But that does matter for a society because now there is an example of a white police officer who took the life of a black man on camera in front of everyone and he went away for a really long time. Now it's not as long as some people would have wanted some social justice advocates. I don't know what the Floyd family was hoping for 30 years. But nobody can dispute the fact that this was a substantive sentence for a killer. And we sought other members of the police force get up there and say we don't teach people to do that. He is not one of us. This is not how we do things. And I think that all of that is incredibly important. Those are two good things.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: That I agree with you but that's what so tragic about the extrapolation of his act that has reflected on police officers all across the country. I mean, that's what so devastating about it. And I think back to that night in Minneapolis when Mayor Jacob Frey told those police officers in the third precinct get out of there. That to me, that was one of the most crucial turning point of the entire summer that followed. Because he didn't say we've got your back, hold the fort, we are going to make sure that we, you know, we quell what's going on outside this precinct. They got in their cars and they rode away. They never got over that, those police officers. They never got over it. They abandoned their post. People ran in there. They flooded the entire place, they emptied the filing cabinets. It was so repulsive I think in such a deep way. And Jacob Frey, so now they're having elections to the city council where they all said they were going to reimagine the police force after that, right? And now, what's happened is that everyone on that city council, they didn't meet the margin of 60 percent so they now have to basically go to a runoff.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So now Jacob Frey also is expected he is the refund the police man now, Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right. Right.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, he's expected to win in that election.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, that's the biggest problem with the consequences of the aftermath of the situation because the left took this case and apply it to every single police department across the country no matter if it's in a big city, in small town, all cops are racist, they had to be defunded. You had a number of Democratic city councils and mayors all over the place, Portland, Minneapolis, Baltimore, defunding the police and then all of a sudden crime goes up by. you know, murders are up 50 percent in some places. In Portland homicide is up by 500 plus percent in that city. And now all of a sudden you have the president this week coming in with essentially a crime bail out for these blue cities by saying you can take money from the American Rescue Act to refund your police forces that you took millions of dollars away from because you were buying into this narrative. That by the way, the prosecution didn't use it in court. The prosecution said Derek Chauvin is one officer in a force. He murdered George Floyd. That was the argument they made. The jury agreed with them. But the left took it and applied it to everybody else and we had a year of rage and summers of burning. And you have the White House now trying to get out in front of another summer like that because police are leaving in droves, people are not signing up to replace the people who are retiring. And people want more police in their communities. And so, there are consequences to applying the situation to everyone rather than just taking the fact as they were for this one case.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: We go back to the summer, Greg, and you know, you remember during the election, how much the need to reform police was such a big topic and now, you know, this is like front and center on the place of President Biden and Kamala Harris and you know, now we're at a whole different stage of this. But they are still, you know, dealing with an issue that became difficult for them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, what do we do now? Our politicians and our media decided to use this case to indict the entire -- our entire national police force, which led to the defunding, led to the Ferguson effect, dramatic shocking rise in crime in which most of the victims were black and brown. Right? I mean, they're all in cities that really needed law enforcement. And the law enforcement was no longer there. That created a mountain of dead. And that was driven by, in my view, like - - just taking a -- they are something like 25 to 30 cases like this every year out of millions and millions of stops and they're horrible and they're tragic, and that was -- the guy is going away for a long time. But we didn't spend any time really on that Puerto Rican couple.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know? From the parade who were pulled out of their car and murdered.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And I keep thinking about that one because there are so many horrible criminal acts that have been going on that the media decides is not important. It's not important. It is important when the police officer does something because of the job that they hold, they're in authority figure and it places until the racial elements. But when you think about OK, if you play through your mind and you find the very worst things, that crime turn my stomach because you saw it. It's as bad as what we saw with the police.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: It's horrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's horrible. And I wonder what would have happened if the cops were there. They weren't there, and they had stopped that crime and they had shot one of the suspects? How would the media portrayed that when that husband and wife are alive and the kids now still have their parents, but there is a dead suspect or an injured suspect. How would that have been portrayed if the cop --it would be in entirely different story and there be -- I have no idea what it would be like. I could predict that the police would be portrayed in a favorable way.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well we know, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: LeBron James when you had that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- that police officer in Ohio who shot that girl who was stabbing the other girl.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Immediately blew up as a racial incident of police violence when he saved the life of a young black girl.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And so, you know, they've racialized all of these situations immediately when they come out, rather than waiting for the facts and treating each case as an individual situation rather than smearing all police officers as being like Derek Chauvin.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And each case is different.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There aren't a lot of them. So, you could act, if you were a journalist you could sit down and actually read about every single case like this --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- it'd be done in three weeks and come to the conclusion that there are all sorts of variables involved from police incompetence, right? Police brutality, substances, crowd control, all of these things play a role differently, each one of them. But the media cannot abide by that. They cannot look at the nuances, it all has to be black and white and black versus white.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, there is some nuance which I think is really interesting between media coverage and actually public approval of law enforcement and what people want. And Eric Adams, who looks to becoming the new mayor of New York has already started talking about that. Of New York City.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: You know, and he is a police officer and there is high approval for law enforcement. People want more cops in their areas especially blacks --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Yes. Because they have seen the reality of what happens when they're gone.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I mean, this is what happened. Right? There were major consequences to this narrative that, you know, basically discouraged police from doing their job all across the country. Somebody has to -- somebody has to pay the piper for that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the white liberal -- it's the white liberal mayor.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I mean, it is unreal what happened. No. Yes, it is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean, think about -- think about Portland.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And think about Minneapolis.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: And thankfully the jury in this case and the way it was prosecuted for Derek Chauvin, they did isolate it. And that's what America should have done.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Said, this is what happened. This is wrong and we need to fix it. And you know, today we have a sentence for him. So. All right. So, here's what's coming up. A totally different topic. Actually, whisper this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: President Biden whispered at a press conference and it caused quite a story. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, the hash tag creepy Joe trending on Twitter after a truly bizarre moment when President Biden aggressively whispered into a microphone. Viewer warning, it's pretty weird.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: They said that people are waiting for relief.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: I got them $1.9 trillion release so far. They are going to getting checks in the mail that are consequential this week for child care. Just remind them, I wrote the bill on the environment. Why would I not before it? Pay them more. This is an employee's -- employee's bargaining chip now what's happening?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Greg, I just imagine Joe Biden doing the whisper thing while he is touching or sniffing someone's hair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. Does he know that everyone can hear him? Like generally when you whisper --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I couldn't hear him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- when you whisper, it so people can't hear you, but he is whispering and everybody can hear him because he's got a microphone. Look, it's one to -- like why is he doing this? Because he's pretending that he's stating something that is obvious. Right. Pay them more. Except that's a really stupid comment. It's kind of stupid.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's really dumb.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's like that's not the beginning and the end of an opinion although he would be really great as a character in a horror movie. I was discussing this earlier that if they ever do a horror film that takes place in an abandoned library and there's this bat story where there was a male librarian who had been like, attacked by crazed kids, and he was left to die, and then he -- but he's still there. And then like years later, these other kids show up at the library, and it's whisper. They call him Whispering Joe. It sounds like a great (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: It sounds like something out of a hot -- like Hogwarts. He could be like -- right? He'd come right in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Whispering at you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: But, Jessica, they could also call the movie Good Old Joe, right? Because this is a habit that he has apparently. You've done your research.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, I like to come prepared.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, you're saying we're not prepared?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I like how Katie just insulted you with research.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, not the girls, babies. So, I did my research on it. He doesn't speak in a clear and concise way. And he gets frustrated, so he has three tells. The first tell is, come on, man. And that's Joe giving up. That's Joe knowing he can't convince you with an actual sentence. It's just, come on man. And then the other tell is the anger, the finger, the wagging, and the flash of the temper. That's when he gets frustrated that he's not communicating. The third tell is the whisper. The whisper is Joe lowering his cadence because he never does that. Because he's very boring, he lowers his cadence, and he comes down, and he tries to reassure the audience that everything is OK. I have things under control. I'm cutting a deal, I'm doing a great job. And that's the way a limited guy like Joe Biden communicates sometimes. And I hate to agree with you, Jessica. And then she talks about the fact that everything that was considered old or feudalist was taken out and smashed. So, they're just taking out these phrases and smashing them. So, I am -- I'm worried. You know, maybe I'm crazy, but I look at all this stuff and I think this is scary. This is scary. And you're so right. You're going to pay all that money to -- what are these teachers doing? And those graduates, do they understand the Civil War, World War I, World War II? Do they understand how the country works? Or are they just kind of graduate thinking like, oh, my gosh, someone just said trigger warning to me, and I'm feeling a little triggered. It's really -- it's scary. So, I just keep going back to this woman and remembering what she said about growing up in China.

The administrators who are getting paid exorbitant amount of money, which is why the tuition is so high, because the administration has grown so much at these colleges. It's the tyranny of the few versus the cowardice of the majority. This is -- this is the root of every major revolution. And so, we can sit here and go like, yes, it's OK.
